title.value: On the importance of catalyst-adsorbate 3D interactions for relaxed energy predictions
title.justification: Accurately reflects the focus and scope of this paper.
title.quote: On the importance of catalyst-adsorbate 3D interactions for relaxed energy predictions

extractions.description: This paper investigates if it is possible to predict the relaxed energy of systems in the OC20 dataset while ignoring the relative position of the adsorbate to the catalyst. The study leverages ML models such as SchNet, DimeNet++, and FAENet, applying modifications to measure the impact on model performance.

type.justification: The paper conducts experiments on modified machine learning models to measure their performance on energy predictions.
type.quote: To achieve this, we propose four modifications of existing GNN architectures, collectively referred to as Disconnected GNNs. All four modifications enable the base architecture to make relaxed energy predictions without explicitly modeling geometric interactions between the adsorbate and the catalyst. We then evaluate the trade-off of omitting these interactions through experiments on the OC20 dataset and suggest future directions to overcome the limits associated with the input adslab configuration.

name.justification: The study focuses on using machine learning to predict material properties, specifically relaxed energy in the context of catalyst-adsorbate interactions.
name.quote: The use of machine learning for material property prediction and discovery has traditionally centered on graph neural networks that incorporate the geometric configuration of all atoms.

name.justification: The study heavily involves different GNN architectures like SchNet, DimeNet++, and FAENet.
name.quote: We consider SchNet, DimeNet++ and FAENet as base architectures and measure the impact of four modifications on model performance

name.justification: The study is centered around predicting properties of catalyst-adsorbate systems, which is a core aspect of catalysis research.
name.quote: In recent years, ML has emerged as a crucial tool for the discovery of electro-catalysts, which play a key role in promoting renewable energy processes and sustainable chemical production, including the production of ammonia for fertilizers and hydrogen.

name.justification: The target outcome of the models is the prediction of relaxed energy in catalysis systems.
name.quote: This dataset was specifically designed to train ML models to predict the relaxed energy of 3D adsorbate-catalyst (adslab) systems, a critical property that influences a catalyst’s activity and selectivity

name.justification: SchNet is one of the base architectures used for modified GNN models in the study.
name.quote: We consider SchNet, DimeNet++ and FAENet as base architectures and measure the impact of four modifications on model performance

is_contributed.justification: SchNet is an existing model used as a baseline and not a contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: In this paper, we investigate the effect of the proposed Disconnected GNN architecture on three backbone models: SchNet [Schütt et al., 2017], DimeNet++ [Klicpera et al., 2020] and FAENet [Duval et al., 2023].

is_executed.justification: The performance of SchNet is evaluated with modifications in this study.
is_executed.quote: We then evaluate the trade-off of omitting these interactions through experiments on the OC20 dataset and suggest future directions to overcome the limits associated with the input adslab configuration.

is_compared.justification: SchNet is compared to DimeNet++ and FAENet.
is_compared.quote: We consider SchNet, DimeNet++ and FAENet as base architectures and measure the impact of four modifications on model performance

referenced_paper_title.value: SchNet: A continuous-filter convolutional neural network for modeling quantum interactions
referenced_paper_title.justification: The original paper on SchNet is referenced for background.

name.justification: The paper examines four modifications collectively called Disconnected GNNs to predict relaxed energy without explicitly modeling geometric interactions between the adsorbate and the catalyst.
name.quote: To achieve this, we propose four modifications of existing GNN architectures, collectively referred to as Disconnected GNNs. All four modifications enable the base architecture to make relaxed energy predictions without explicitly modeling geometric interactions between the adsorbate and the catalyst.

is_contributed.justification: The Disconnected GNNs are a novel contribution of this study.
is_contributed.quote: To achieve this, we propose four modifications of existing GNN architectures, collectively referred to as Disconnected GNNs.

is_executed.justification: The modified GNN models (Disconnected GNNs) are evaluated in the study.
is_executed.quote: We then evaluate the trade-off of omitting these interactions through experiments on the OC20 dataset and suggest future directions to overcome the limits associated with the input adslab configuration.

is_compared.justification: The Disconnected GNNs are compared with SchNet, DimeNet++, and FAENet.
is_compared.quote: We consider SchNet, DimeNet++ and FAENet as base architectures and measure the impact of four modifications on model performance

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no separate reference paper for 'Disconnected GNNs' as they are introduced in this study.

name.justification: The OC20 dataset is used for training and evaluating the models in this study.
name.quote: This dataset was specifically designed to train ML models to predict the relaxed energy of 3D adsorbate-catalyst (adslab) systems, a critical property that influences a catalyst’s activity and selectivity [Tran and Ulissi, 2018], or its effectiveness for a specific chemical reaction

referenced_paper_title.value: Open Catalyst 2020 (OC20) Dataset and Community Challenges
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides details about the OC20 dataset used in this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Open Catalyst Project (OCP) [Chanussot et al., 2021] has significantly contributed to this field by releasing an extensive dataset of 1,281,040 DFT relaxations of catalyst-adsorbate pairs, selected from a pool of meanigful candidates

name.justification: PyTorch is mentioned as part of the machine learning framework used in these models.
name.quote: All models and experiments use the PyTorch framework.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The original paper on PyTorch is referenced for background.
